content:
Add this to userContent.css: 

::-moz-selection {   color: red;   background: yellow; }


https://www.w3schools.com/howto/howto_css_text_selection.asp

Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Directory (Win: Folder), close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userContent.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the colours as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)
creator: sfhowes

content:

The ::-moz I wouldn't have found, just from lack of familiarity of the tbird internals post ver. 3.x when the version race took off. Already had toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets set true and had a userChrome.css and created the new userContent.css. Finally the dark theme is tweaked to my aging eyes aren't straining to see which character the selection begins on.

content: - install the addon, importexporttools NG, if not already done - highlight Local Folders, rightclick, select the importexport option to import mbox - then, select a desired old folder (ignore msf entries) and click ok to import - repeat for each folder - if you wish to merge with an IMAP folder, create a manual filter to do the transfer. this slows the process a bit to minimize data loss since IMAP was not designed for high volume uploads
creator: davidsk

content: You have activated the Quick Filter "Show only messages with attachments". (see image) As long as your spam messages don't contain attachments, TB won't display any message in the thread pane. Close your Quick Filter and your spam messages will be displayed in the thread pane.....

content:
1) Do not do any banking by email 2) Do not automatically trust any email involving money 3) Your security should be multi-layered and strong, using some of the items in the links below. If you have trouble or are not able to navigate the technical aspects you should get the help of someone you trust.

This has specific recommendations for Thunderbird, including https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird/privacy-and-security

That has recommendations for email in general.

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: Assuming you're using OAuth2 authentication for your Gmail account, the authentication token Thunderbird remembered does expire every once in a while. When that happens Gmail will prompt you to re-authenticate.

content: Try this: Settings/Privacy & Security, Saved Passwords, remove all entries for the account, restart TB, enter the working password (confirmed in webmail), check the box to save it in Saved Passwords. This should work, unless there is an external password manager of the kind included in some security apps.

content:
You're absolutely correct, Wayne! I had COMPLETELY forgotten about the exact same glitch two years ago.

Getting older every day and for the life of me, cannot recall how I resolved it...at least temporarily. I do recall that earthlink was no help at all. All they wanted to do was sell me more products. They said it was a TB issue.

I must have figured something out, because for the past few years, I've only gotten the error message occasionally and I just blew it off by hitting cancel. But now, the old EM has returned with a vengeance that can't be tamed. Just now, while we're chatting, yet another just popped up, probably the 20th of the day thus far.

Just can't seem to get the settings the way TB wants. I mean, there's absolutely no problem with sending or receiving emails. That's not the issue at all. It's just the darn error message. It's a glitch that I can't figure out.

That's for taking the time with the issue. Really appreciate the help - and the reminder of how my mind is slipping away!

Lenny

content:
Try this: Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, delete or rename logins.json, key4.db and cert9.db. This will remove all passwords. Restart TB, enter the password, check the box, and see if the problem remains.

You didn't say if there is an external password manager in use.

Confirm your settings: pop.earthlink.net, 995, SSL/TLS, normal password, email address; smtpauth.earthlink.net, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, email address

https://help.earthlink.net/portal/en/kb/articles/email-server-settings

content:
Sorry, correction to the above: I see now that the default behavior is for the focus to be in the to: field, even in a Reply or Reply-All scenario -- but I also see that the focus skips briefly to the Body, and then back to the To: field. So it's still an issue (I still have the very real problem of sending emails to the wrong people).

Not sure what the intended behavior is. I feel like in a Reply or Reply-All scenario, the focus should jump to the body because the To: field is already loaded with addresses. But that is a design decision, vs. what I consider a bit of a bug here at the moment -- the focus jumping from To: to body and then back to To: (but only if you don't type in the body... so, with the timing of my typing, I get the results described in my initial post above).

content: Ok, wrong folder. The profile folder would have been at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<profilefolder> and the name of the profile itself would be at c\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini - replace the <yourid> with yours

creator: markwarner22

content:
Version 128 is the ESR version that is updated once a year, while 137 is the new 'release' version updated at least monthly, like Firefox. You can update 128 to 137 by manually downloading the 137 installer from thunderbird.net, at least with Windows. The newer version should read the existing profile without issue. On Linux, updating is usually done through the distro's update mechanism. I don't think there's any great advantage to having both on 137, and there might be some advantages as 128 is possibly more stable.

As to why the laptop with 137 won't download, I can think of an example such as AT&T accounts that require a different secure mail key for each computer, even for the same account. It might help if you post any error messages.
creator: sfhowes

content: Generally, to reset your password, you need to log onto your online account to do that. ll thunderbird does is take the new password from you and store it so that it can send to server when requested.
